en: I mean, they are mine, because it’s my handwriting, but I didn’t write them.
zh: 我的意思是說，它們是我寫的，因為這是我的筆跡，但我並沒有寫它們。

en: I mean, okay, I wrote them, but I don’t remember writing them.
zh: 我的意思是說，好吧，我寫了它們，但我不記得了。

en: The words are big and black, written with a marker, like a point being forced, and I can only assume Henry wrote them, Henry who would wear the author’s hat, Henry who sometimes occupies my thoughts and takes control of my life.
zh: 這些字又黑又粗，有點兒像是被逼迫著用黑色記號筆寫的。我只能假定是亨利寫的，亨利是我的作家帽子，他有時控制我的思想，佔據我的身體。

en: I don’t know when he wrote them, or why.
zh: 我不知道他是什麼時候寫的這些字，或者他為什麼要寫。

en: I’ve spent all morning thinking about it, and this is what I’ve come up with—nothing.
zh: 我已經花了一上午時間用來思考這件事，但什麼也沒有。

en: Eric has been asking me questions about the diary, about my past.
zh: 艾瑞克一直在問我日記和我過去的事。

en: My life is like a jigsaw puzzle to him, and I’m not sure why he’s so interested, but he is.
zh: 對他而言，我的生活像是一個難解的謎圖案，我不知道他為什麼這麼感興趣，但他偏偏就是很感興趣。

en: It turns out—and I don’t know if this is more sad or funny—that one of the reasons he asked me to keep a diary is because I confessed to a crime that never happened. I don’t even remember confessing—but he was telling me I’ve been getting a little mixed-up between what is real and what is make-believe.
zh: 事實證明——我不知道應該感到悲傷還是可笑——他要我寫日記的原因之一是我會承認虛構的罪行。

en: When he first told me, I thought it was the setup to some awful joke.
zh: 當他第一次告訴我時，我認為這是一個恐怖的玩笑。

en: The more he insisted, the madder I got at what felt like an accusation.
zh: 他越是堅持，我越是覺得他要告發我。

en: Finally, another of the nurses confirmed it was true.
zh: 最後，一位護士確認這是真的。

en: I’ve been telling people—telling and really insisting—that I kept a woman locked in my basement for two weeks before killing her, which would be a really neat trick since I’ve never owned a house with a basement.
zh: 我一直在對人們說——一直在堅持地說——我把一個女人鎖在我的地下室里兩個星期，然後殺死了她。這確實是瞎話，因為我根本就沒有帶地下室的房子。

en: Eric is trying to convince me to write in the diary every day, because he thinks it will help ground me to what is real.
zh: 艾瑞克想方設法地說服我每天寫日記，因為他認為這將有助於我記錄真實可信的記憶。

en: I hide it in my drawer when I’m not writing in it.
zh: 我不寫日記時，就把它藏在我的抽屜里。

en: I remember I had a floorboard under my desk that I could pry up, but I can’t remember where the second one is.
zh: 我記得我書桌下有一塊地板，可以撬起來，但我記不得第二個在哪裡了。

en: Today is a bad day.
zh: 今天是一個糟糕的日子。

en: It’s bad because I can remember that Sandra (my wife) is dead, and that Eva (my daughter) never comes to see me.
zh: 說它糟糕是因為我可以記得桑德拉（我的妻子）死了，伊娃（我的女兒）也從來不過來看我。

en: Looking back at the previous entries it seems I only write when I’m having a good day.
zh: 回顧以前的篇目，我似乎只有在美好的日子里才會動手寫日記的。

en: I should start putting in the date, because I have no idea how long I’m going between entries.
zh: 我應該按日期去寫的，因為我不知道要用多久才會開始寫下一篇。

en: Don’t trust Hans.
zh: 「不要相信漢斯。」

en: I don’t know why I would have written that.
zh: 我不知道為什麼我會寫那些字。

en: Why Henry would have.
zh: 為什麼亨利會寫。

en: And yet . . with those words is some kind of recognition, a sense that I have written them before.
zh: 但是，那些文字我似曾相識，我隱隱有種寫過它們的感覺。

en: If I had to guess, then I would say perhaps it was in the original Crazy Diary.
zh: 要我猜的話，我會說，也許我在原來的「狂人日記」里寫過。

en: This is Version II—Version I was written as Jerry’s Normal Life phase entered the Madness phase.
zh: 這是版本二的日記，版本一是在傑瑞從正常步入瘋狂時寫就的。

en: I miss Sandra.
zh: 我想念桑德拉。

en: I know she’s dead, but I don’t know know, if that makes sense.
zh: 我知道她死了，但我不知道為什麼我會知道。

en: It’s like having somebody come along and tell you the sky is green when it’s actually blue.
zh: 這就像有人過來告訴你天空是綠色的，而它明明是藍色的。

en: That’s how it feels, and the memory of those few days with her lying on the floor are feeling more and more like they belong to somebody else, that they belong to one of the characters I’ve given life to.
zh: 就是那種感覺，她躺在地板上那幾天的記憶越來越像是屬於別人的，屬於我曾在書中賦予過生命的某個人物。

en: Don’t trust Hans.
zh: 「不要相信漢斯。」

en: Really?
zh: 真的嗎？

en: I’m off to breakfast now (good news?
zh: 我要去吃早餐了（好消息？

en: For some reason I have the urge to say that—but nothing really to say).
zh: 不知道為什麼我很想說這個，但又什麼都說不出來）。

en: Oh, and thinking about it, I think I should be calling this a Madness Diary, not a . . .
zh: 哦，想想，我想我應該把它叫作日記，而不是一個……等等，剛才說的不算。「狂人日記」，這才是更恰如其分的名字。

en: Once again, Jerry is able to recall writing these journal entries. But he can’t remember the actual events described.
zh: 傑瑞能夠記得寫過這些篇目，但他記不得所描述的具體事件了。

en: For all intents and purposes, this is the Madness Journal of a stranger..
zh: 結合所有的文字來看，這是一個出自陌生人之手的「狂人日記」。

en: It lines up with what Current Jerry thinks, because that will be where the original journal is hidden.
zh: 與「當前的傑瑞」所想的一致，這是原來的日記的藏匿之處。

en: He reads the next entry and it’s more of the same, as is the following one, words that belong to him but are somehow associated with someone else.
zh: 他閱讀下一篇，和剛才一樣，所有的詞語他都似曾相識，但似乎又與他人有關。

en: He puts the journal down. He moves to the doorway and listens for movement.
zh: 他放下日記，走到門口聽聽動靜。

en: Hans is no longer in the garage but definitely somewhere in the house.
zh: 漢斯不在車庫裡，而是在別的地方。

en: He can hear his friend opening and closing drawers.
zh: 他可以聽到他的朋友打開和關上抽屜的聲音。

en: Don’t trust Hans.
zh: 「不要相信漢斯」。

en: The earlier entry was clear on that, but didn’t provide an explanation.
zh: 上一篇寫得很清楚了，但沒有解釋。

en: It could have just as easily warned: don’t trust Henry. Or don’t trust Jerry, because he sure as hell can’t trust himself, can he?
zh: 就像之前的警告：不要相信亨利，或者不要相信傑瑞，因為他肯定不能相信自己的，對吧？

en: If Hans isn’t to be trusted, if the author with the Alzheimer’s monkey on his back is to be believed, then standing in the doorway isn’t the way to go about finding an answer to all this.
zh: 如果漢斯不值得信任，那麼得了阿爾茨海默病的作家也不值得信任。站在門口是找不到答案的，也無法面對他的朋友，他坐回桌子後面，拿起日記。

en: He rolls up his sleeve and looks at the marks on his arm. An idea is coming to him.
zh: 他捲起衣袖，看著他手臂上的針痕，腦海中浮現出一個想法。

en: He looks back at the journal. Chunks of it have been stolen and inserted directly into Eric’s manuscript and portrayed as the journal entries of his protagonist.
zh: 日記中成段成段的內容被剽竊，被直接用於艾瑞克的手稿當中，充當他的主角的日記篇目。

en: These entries come off as very realistic because they come from a genuine source.
zh: 這些篇章非常真實，因為它們來源本就是真實的。

en: They are the ramblings of a madman.
zh: 它們是一個瘋子的胡言亂語。

en: Mad, he thinks, because Eric made him that way.
zh: 他心想，他是瘋了，是艾瑞克把他弄成這樣的。

en: The same way he’s able to predict the ending to nearly every movie and TV show he’s seen, the same way he knows what’s waiting for him on the last page of any novel.
zh: 他可以預測他看過的每部電影和電視劇的結局，同樣，他也可以預測任何一部小說最後一頁寫的收場。

en: He knows that Eric injected him not just on the days he was going out and hurting those women, but also on days he couldn’t push his story forward.
zh: 他知道艾瑞克不僅在出去殺害那些女人的日子里給他注射鎮靜劑，還在他的小說寫不下去的日子里也給他注射。

en: Eric would inject him just for the purpose of making Jerry’s world more miserable than it is, just so Jerry would write about it.
zh: 艾瑞克給他注射鎮靜劑只是為了使傑瑞的世界更凄慘，然後傑瑞才會繼續寫下去。

en: He carries on with the journal.
zh: 他繼續往下閱讀日記。

en: Here’s the first instance of being found wandering in town.
zh: 這篇寫著他第一次進城遊盪被發現的經過。

en: Past Jerry has no memory of it, and nobody knows how he got there.
zh: 「過去的傑瑞」對此毫無記憶，沒有人知道他是如何到達那裡的。

en: He reads the entry slowly, looking for the details, but there are none except for a gold locket that Past Jerry finds in his pocket that evening when he’s back in the nursing home.
zh: 他細細讀著這一篇，尋找著蛛絲馬跡，但裏面除了提到「過去的傑瑞」回到療養院的當天晚上，在他的口袋發現一個黃金小盒之外，沒有別的有價值的信息。

en: He thinks he must have stolen it, so he hides it in the back of one of his drawers.
zh: 他一度認為是自己偷走了它，所以把它藏在一個抽屜裏面。

en: Current Jerry tilts his head back and closes his eyes and tries to think back to the phone call he had earlier today with Eva.
zh: 「當前的傑瑞」歪著頭，閉上眼睛，回想著今天早些時候與伊娃通電話的情形。

en: She said the jewelry was found there, jewelry from the women who were killed.
zh: 她說，有人在療養院里發現被殺害的女人的首飾。

en: Eric must have given those pieces to him.
zh: 一定是艾瑞克把那些東西給他的。

en: What if the next entry is Past Jerry detailing how he escapes, how much he enjoys a good, old-fashioned bloodletting? What if?
zh: 如果下一篇寫的是「過去的傑瑞」詳細敘說他如何逃離療養院，又是多麼享受老套的殺人方法又怎麼辦？

en: Only he doesn’t think it will.
zh: 他不認為那是真的。

en: He’s not that guy.
zh: 他不會是那種人的。

en: Like he told Hans earlier, Sandra would never have married that guy.
zh: 就像他早先告訴漢斯的那樣，桑德拉是不會和這種殺人狂魔結婚的。

en: And like Hans told you, buddy, the Alzheimer’s is a wild card.
zh: 但又正如漢斯告訴你的那樣，夥計，阿爾茨海默病仍舊是個未知數。

en: Following entries find Past Jerry confessing to more crimes from his books: a couple of homicides, a bank robbery, a kidnapping, even to being a drug dealer.
zh: 在下面的篇目中，「過去的傑瑞」承認了更多他書中描繪過的罪行：兇殺、搶劫、綁架，乃至販毒。

en: He wonders if this was a natural progression, or something Eric orchestrated for his research.
zh: 他納悶這到底是他自己循序漸進呢，還是艾瑞克為他謀划好的。

en: Past Jerry is found once again wandering in town, and when he’s taken back to the nursing home he finds another piece of jewelry in his pocket, and he has no memory of how he left the home.
zh: 「過去的傑瑞」再次被發現在城裡遊盪，他被帶回療養院，他在口袋裡發現了另一件首飾，但他不記得是如何離開療養院的。

en: “Jerry?” Hans, calling from somewhere in the house.
zh: 「傑瑞？」漢斯在房子里的某個地方喊，「傑瑞，到這裏來一下。」

en: Don’t trust Hans, Henry says.
zh: 「不要相信漢斯。」亨利說。

en: But how can he not?
zh: 但他怎麼能不相信他呢？

en: After everything Hans has done for him?
zh: 尤其是在看到漢斯為他所做的一切之後。

en: He finds Hans in the master bedroom, the bed shoved to one side of the room, the contents of the drawers tipped out, clothes on the floor, jewelry forming a pile on the bed.
zh: 他在主卧找到漢斯，床被推到房間的一側，抽屜里的雜物被翻了出來，地板上到處是衣服，床上放著成堆的首飾。

en: “You think some of that belongs to the girls?”
zh: 「你認為這些屬於那些女孩嗎？」

en: Jerry asks, looking at the rings and necklaces and earrings.
zh: 傑瑞看著戒指、項鏈和耳環問。

en: “I don’t know. Probably his wife’s.
zh: 「我不知道，也有可能是他妻子的。

en: But that’s not why I called you,” he says, and he holds up an eight-by-ten envelope.
zh: 但我不是為這事叫你的。」他說著，舉起一個信封，「看看這個。」

en: Jerry is expecting more rings and necklaces to slide out. He’s expecting something that can explain what happened to the woman whose house he woke up in today.
zh: 傑瑞期待有更多的戒指和項鏈從信封里滑出來，期待著有什麼證據可以解釋那個女人身上到底發生了什麼事情，自己為什麼早上醒來會在她家。

en: And that’s exactly what he gets. Four small ziplocked plastic bags and four photographs that together tell a story.
zh: 這是他看到的：四個小拉鏈塑料袋和四張照片，它們構建在一起共同講述著一個故事。

en: “I found it taped under the bottom drawer,” Hans says.
zh: 「我發現這些粘在抽屜底部。」漢斯說，「這個該死的業餘殺手。」

en: Jerry reaches out to pick up one of the bags.
zh: 傑瑞伸手想拿起一個袋子。

en: “Don’t touch them,” Hans says. “Don’t get your prints on them.”
zh: 「不要碰，」漢斯說，「不要在上面留下你的指紋。」

en: “Why not?
zh: 「為什麼？

en: The police are going to know I was here.”
zh: 警察會知道我在這裏的。」

en: “We don’t want them thinking you brought these things with you.”
zh: 「我們不想讓他們以為你會隨身帶著這些東西。」

en: “What are they?”
zh: 「這些都是什麼？」

en: Jerry asks, pulling his hands back.
zh: 傑瑞抽回雙手問。

en: “It’s hair.”
zh: 「頭髮。」

en: “What?”
zh: 「什麼？」

en: “Four bags, four victims.
zh: 「四袋，四名受害者。

en: He took jewelry to plant on you, and he took hair for himself.
zh: 他拿珠寶嫁禍於你，自己卻拿了頭髮。

en: He probably found it more personal.”
zh: 他可能覺得它更有具個性化特點一些。」

en: “And the photographs?”
zh: 「照片呢？」

en: The photographs have all landed facedown.
zh: 照片全部面朝下放著。

en: Except the last one shows Jerry Grey in the background, snoozing on the couch.
zh: 只有最後一張例外，照片的背景是坐在沙發上打盹的傑瑞·格雷。

en: The horror at what these girls went through is too much for Jerry, and he finds he can’t speak.
zh: 這些女孩的死狀讓傑瑞驚恐萬狀，他哽咽著說不出話來。

en: “You didn’t do this,” Hans says.
zh: 「不是你乾的。」漢斯說。

en: “That doesn’t make what happened to them any less painful.”
zh: 「但這不會減輕她們的痛苦。」

en: “No, but it means you’re not responsible.”
zh: 「對，但這也意味著你沒有責任。」

en: “Not directly, no,” Jerry says.
zh: 「沒有直接責任，沒有。」傑瑞說。

en: “You want to explain that?”
zh: 「你能解釋一下經過嗎？」

en: “Eric killed them because I told him he had to write what he knows.
zh: 「艾瑞克殺了她們，因為我告訴他，寫他所知道的。

en: He killed them because he knew he could get away with it by framing me.
zh: 於是他就真的殺了她們，因為他知道他還可以嫁禍給我，逃避法律的制裁。

en: If I’d never gotten sick, if I were still at home and still had my old life, then I’d have never met Eric.
zh: 如果我沒有生病，如果我還在家裡，過著我以前的生活，那麼我就不會認識艾瑞克。

en: Those girls would still be alive.”
zh: 那些女孩還可以活著。」

en: “It doesn’t work that way.
zh: 「不是那樣的。

en: If it did, we’d all be responsible for everybody else’s actions all the time.
zh: 如果是這樣，我們就該對世界上所有人的行為負責了。

en: Eric did this, not you.
zh: 這些是艾瑞克做的，不是你。

en: You didn’t hurt these girls, Eric did,” Hans says.
zh: 你沒有殺害過這些女孩，是艾瑞克乾的。」漢斯說。

en: Together, Jerry thinks, they have just taken care of a serial killer.
zh: 傑瑞認為，他們抓到了一個連環殺手。

en: “There is one small problem,” Hans adds, and any relief Jerry was starting to feel at not being a killer disappears, replaced by a sinking feeling in his stomach.
zh: 「還有一個小問題。」漢斯補充說。傑瑞剛剛還因為自己不是殺手而如釋重負，聽到他朋友這麼說，一種不祥的念頭又襲來了。「什麼問題？」

en: “The police are going to think you planted them here.”
zh: 「警察會認為你偽造了現場。」

en: Jerry doesn’t know what to say.
zh: 傑瑞一時不知道該說什麼。

en: Henry, on the other hand, knows. He’s absolutely right, but that doesn’t mean you should trust him.
zh: 亨利也知道，他說得完全正確，但這也並不意味著你應該相信他。

en: “But the photographs—”
zh: 「但那些照片——」

en: “Could have been taken by you.”
zh: 「可能是你拍攝的。」

en: “Not the last one.”
zh: 「最後一張不是。」

en: “Could have been taken with a self-timer.”
zh: 「可能是用自|拍定時器相機。」

en: “The police will figure out when these photographs were printed, and where, and will see it was probably on Eric’s computer.”
zh: 「警察會查清這些照片是什麼時候列印出來的、是在哪裡列印的，而且最終會發現是在艾瑞克電腦上。」

en: “Which you’ve had access to,” Hans counters.
zh: 「你看他的電腦了？」漢斯說。

en: “Not for long, though.”
zh: 「看了，但時間不長。」

en: “They won’t know that.
zh: 「他們不會知道的。

en: The police might think you’ve been here all day, after leaving the knife at the mall.
zh: 警察可能認為你在商店裡丟掉刀以後，一整天都待在這裏。

en: Look, Jerry, in saying all of that, I think you’ll be okay.
zh: 你看吧，傑瑞，推論到這裏，我想你會沒事的。

en: At the very least it will mean they’ll investigate him, right?
zh: 至少這意味著他們會調查他，對吧？

en: They’re going to look into all the days those girls were killed, and they’re going to find a pattern.
zh: 他們會對這些女孩被殺的所有日子進行調查，他們會發現另一種作案手法。

en: Maybe they’ll rip the place apart and find even more evidence. Maybe they’ll find some poor girl buried out in the garden.
zh: 他們會掘地三尺對這個地方進行地毯式的搜查，找到更多的證據，更有可能他們會發現一些可憐的女孩被埋在花園裡。

en: It could be the wife suspected something too, and she might talk.
zh: 他妻子還可能會起疑心，她可能會告訴別人。

en: Could be this jewelry that belongs to the wife originally came from the girls.”
zh: 也許他妻子的珠寶首飾原先是這些女孩的。」

en: “But you believe me, right?”
zh: 「但是你相信我，對吧？」

en: “Of course I do, but I’m not the one who needs convincing.
zh: 「我當然相信你，但你需要說服的人並不是我。

en: This guy has been exposed and taken care of because of you, not because of the police, and they’re not going to be too thrilled being made to look foolish by a crime writer dealing with Alzheimer’s. They’re going to look for any angle that could suggest your involvement. The flip side to that is you’ll be cleared, and once the media gets hold of the story, you’ll be a hero.
zh: 一方面，這個傢伙因為你被曝光而被幹掉了，而且不是警察乾的，他們並不會因受到患有阿爾茨海默病的犯罪小說家的捉弄感到興奮不已，他們只會尋找你涉嫌其中的證據。

en: The country won’t like a hero being convicted.”
zh: 國家是不願看到一個英雄被定罪的。」

en: “I’m not a monster,” Jerry says, and the relief is back . . .
zh: 「我不是怪物。」傑瑞說。

en: Hans is staring at him. He has that look he gets when he’s trying to figure something out.
zh: 漢斯凝視著他，露出每當他想要弄清事情的原委的時候就會露出的神情。

en: “What?” Jerry asks.
zh: 「怎麼了？」傑瑞問。

en: “Let’s not forget the others,” Hans says.
zh: 「我們不要忘記其他人。」漢斯說。

en: “What others?”
zh: 「什麼人？」

en: “The others you’ve killed.”
zh: 「被你殺死的人。」

en: Jerry thinks about Sandra, he remembers the florist, and Suzan with a z, whose real name is lost to him now.
zh: 傑瑞想到了桑德拉，想起花店老闆，想起蘇姍，他現在已經記不起她的真實姓名了。

en: He looks down at the photographs, three of them representing women he has killed.
zh: 他看著那些照片，其中三張是他殺死的女人。

en: “Is it possible I haven’t killed anybody?” Jerry asks.
zh: 「有沒有可能我沒有殺死任何人？」傑瑞問。

en: “Two hours ago we dropped a man to his death,” Hans says.
zh: 「兩個小時前，我們剛把一個人給摔死。」漢斯說。

en: “Other than him,” Jerry says.
zh: 「除了他以外。」傑瑞說。

en: “Possible? Anything is possible,” Hans says.
zh: 「可能性嘛……一切皆有可能。」

en: “Anything is possible,” Jerry says, letting the words hang in the air for a few seconds before chasing them with the reality.
zh: 「一切皆有可能。」傑瑞重複著，這個句子在空中懸浮了幾秒鐘，傑瑞才重返現實，「所以，你認為我有可能。」

en: “I’m sorry, buddy.”
zh: 「對不起，夥計。」

en: “So now what?”
zh: 「那麼現在怎麼辦？」

en: “Well I can keep looking around while you read the journal.
zh: 「我再到處看看，你可以繼續讀讀日記。

en: Since he hid these,” Hans says, nodding towards the bags of hair and photographs, “then it stands to reason he might have hidden something else.
zh: 既然他藏了這些，」漢斯說著，沖那些裝頭髮的塑料袋和照片點點頭，「那麼他就有理由藏了別的東西。

en: It’s not uncommon for people to have more than one hiding space.
zh: 人們擁有幾個藏東西的地方並不罕見。

en: Ultimately we —”
zh: 但最終我們——」

en: “That’s right!
zh: 「那就對了！

en: I haven’t told you yet, but I wrote in my journal that there is a second hiding place!”
zh: 我還沒有告訴你，但我在日記中寫著，還有第二個暗格或者密室！」

en: Jerry says.
zh: 傑瑞說。

en: Hans looks excited. “Where?”
zh: 漢斯看起來很興奮：「在哪裡？」

en: “I didn’t say.”
zh: 「我沒有寫。」

en: “Well what did you say?”
zh: 「那你寫什麼了？」

en: “Just that there’s somewhere else. I think it’s where I used to hide my writing backups.”
zh: 「只是還有別的地方，我認為是我以前藏手稿備份的地方。」

en: “Where?”
zh: 「在哪裡？」

en: “I don’t know.”
zh: 「我不知道。」

en: “You need to remember, Jerry,” Hans says, sounding urgent.
zh: 「你需要想起來，傑瑞。」漢斯說，聽起來很急迫，「我們需要到你的房子里去找它。」

en: “I need a drink.”
zh: 「我需要喝杯酒。」

en: “Seriously?”
zh: 「你說真的？」

en: “Who knows when I’ll get another chance?
zh: 「誰知道我還有沒有機會喝呢？

en: Plus it might help me think.”
zh: 再說它可能有助於我思考。」

en: Hans slowly nods. “After all you’ve gone through today, you probably deserve one.
zh: 漢斯緩緩地點點頭：「畢竟你今天經歷的太多了，應該喝一杯。

en: Hell, I think we both do.”
zh: 媽的，我想我們都應該喝一杯。」

en: They head out to the kitchen and Jerry leans against the bench while Hans goes through the cupboards.
zh: 他們走進廚房，傑瑞靠著長凳，漢斯則去看櫥櫃。

en: He finds what he’s looking for. Not quite what he’s looking for—there’s vodka, and no gin, but it will have to do.
zh: 他找到了，卻不是他想要的：裏面有伏特加，但沒有杜松子酒，但也聊勝於無了。

en: He grabs some ice from the freezer. There’s no tonic anywhere, so he ends up making a couple of vodka and orange drinks.
zh: 他從冰箱里拿出一些冰來，那兒也沒有奎寧水，所以最終他倒了幾杯伏特加和橙汁。

en: They sit down at the table. All very social, Jerry thinks.
zh: 他們坐在桌邊，氛圍不錯，傑瑞心想。

en: All very mad, Henry thinks. “Why are you still wearing the gloves?” Jerry asks.
zh: 「你為什麼還戴著手套？」傑瑞問。

en: Don’t trust Hans.
zh: 「不要相信漢斯。」

en: “What do you mean?”
zh: 「你什麼意思？」

en: “With Eric being dead already, the police are going to figure out I’m involved.”
zh: 「艾瑞克已經死了，警察會知道這與我有關。」

en: “That’s right.”
“And when they talk to me, they’re going to figure out you’re involved.”
zh: 「他們會找我談話，他們會知道這與你有關。」

en: “Not if you don’t tell them.”
zh: 「不會，如果你不告訴他們的話。」

en: “You don’t want them to know?”
zh: 「你不想讓他們知道？」

en: “Of course not.
zh: 「當然不想了。

en: I want to help you out, buddy, but I’d also really like to avoid jail too.”
zh: 我只想幫你擺脫干係，夥計，但我也真的不想攤上牢獄之災了。」

en: “What if I forget that and tell them?”
zh: 「如果我忘記了，告訴他們了怎麼辦？」

en: “If you forget, you forget.
zh: 「如果你忘記了，就忘記了。

en: But if you remember, and don’t drag me into it, then the police never need to know I was here.
zh: 但如果你記得，千萬不要把我牽扯進去。警察不需要知道我在這裏。

en: Look, Jerry, I know it’s not right of me to ask this, but I want you to take the fall for what happened to Eric.
zh: 傑瑞，我知道我這樣要求不對，但我想讓你為艾瑞克的死承擔責任。

en: The police will go easy on you, and if they don’t . . .” Hans says, and doesn’t finish.
zh: 警察不會對你太苛刻的，如果他們不——」漢斯頓住了。

en: “If they don’t what?”
zh: 「如果他們不什麼？」

en: “You’re already a killer, mate.
zh: 「你已經是個殺人犯了，夥計。

en: I’m just trying to help. I don’t want to be punished for trying to help you out.”
zh: 我只是想幫助你，但我不想因為幫助你而受到懲罰。」

en: Jerry looks at his glass, then slowly sips from it.
zh: 傑瑞看著他的酒杯，然後慢慢地呷了一口。

en: He sips a little more.
zh: 他又呷了一口。

en: It’s a fair point, he thinks, then tells Hans as such.
zh: 這樣說是公平的，他這麼認為，然後他告訴了漢斯。

en: “You remember my dad’s funeral?” he asks.
zh: 「你還記得我爸爸的葬禮嗎？」他問。

en: Jerry looks up. He shakes his head. He wonders where Hans is going with this.
zh: 傑瑞抬起頭來，他搖搖頭，不知道漢斯要說什麼。

en: “The night before the funeral, you took me into town and we ended up at a bar that had run out of gin.
zh: 「葬禮的前一天晚上，你帶我進城，去了一個酒吧。

en: You started bitching at the bartender, asking him what kind of bar it was, and he said the kind of bar where people who complain get their teeth kicked out.
zh: 他們的杜松子酒賣完了，你就對酒吧服務員罵罵咧咧的，質問他這是什麼爛酒吧，結果服務員說誰要沒事找事就打碎誰的牙齒。

en: We ended up drinking these,” he says, taking a sip. “Only time I’ve ever had them. It’s not . . . I don’t know the word,” he says.
zh: 我們喝光了酒……」他說著，喝了一口酒，「那是我唯一一次……不是……我不知道該用哪個詞。」

en: “Not masculine enough?”
zh: 「不像個男人？」

en: Hans nods. “I knew you’d know.
zh: 漢斯點點頭：「我就知道你會知道的。

en: You’ve always been a gin-and-tonic guy, ever since we met.”
zh: 自從我們認識以來，你一直愛喝加奎寧水的杜松子酒。」

en: Jerry finishes his drink. He considers whether he wants a second.
zh: 傑瑞喝完杯中的酒，考慮是否再來一杯。

en: “I remember you brought bottles to me when I got sick.”
zh: 「我記得我生病時你給我帶了幾瓶。」

en: “Sandra wouldn’t let you drink, and she took your credit card off you so you couldn’t go and buy them.
zh: 「桑德拉不讓你喝酒，她拿走了你的信用卡，所以你也不能買。

en: I would bring five of them to you at a time. I have no idea where you hid them, but maybe it’s the same place you hid the —”
zh: 我一次給你帶去五瓶，我不知道你把它們藏在哪裡，但也許你把它和……藏在同一個地方。」

en: “In the garage,” Jerry says, and he can remember it, can remember a tarpaulin beneath a bench, covering the gap behind the chain saw and the circular saw, and that was where he hid them, behind renovating tools that belonged to a much younger version of Past Jerry, back when Eva was a small girl and his books were still to be given life.
zh: 「在車庫裡。」傑瑞說，他還能記得車庫裡的長凳下面，在鏈鋸和圓鋸後面，有一塊防水帆布，他就把酒藏在那裡，這是屬於更加年輕時候的傑瑞的密室。

en: He didn’t hide all of the bottles there, the rest were under the floor of his office.
zh: 那時，伊娃還是一個小丫頭而已。不過，他沒有把所有的酒都藏在這裏，剩下幾瓶他藏在了寫作房的地板下面。

en: “You got through them pretty quickly,” Hans says.
zh: 「你很快就喝完了。」漢斯說。

en: Only the bottles weren’t under the floor, were they, Jerry?
zh: 「只是那幾瓶酒不在地板下面，對吧，傑瑞？」

en: Henry says. No, under the floor was reserved just for the gun that wasn’t there and the journal that also wasn’t there.
zh: 亨利說，「不，地板下面本來是藏槍的地方，而槍卻不在那裡，日記也不在那裡。

en: The only thing under there was a shirt you can’t remember getting bloody.
zh: 地板下唯一的東西是一件你不知從何而來的血跡斑斑的襯衫。」

en: “I’m sorry about what happened to you,” Hans says.
zh: 「我對發生在你身上的事感到遺憾。」漢斯說，「你已經名聲敗壞。

en: Not one of the worst I’ve ever seen, but pretty damn close.”
zh: 雖然這並不是我見過最糟糕的，但也他媽的差不多了。」

en: Jerry isn’t listening to Hans. Instead he’s listening to Henry.
zh: 傑瑞沒有在聽漢斯講話，而是在聽亨利講話。

en: He’s thinking about the floorboards. About the original journal. How it wasn’t under there. The gin wasn’t under there either.
zh: 他在想著地板，想著原先的那本日記怎麼會不在地板下面，連杜松子酒也不在那裡，槍也不在那裡。

en: Nor the gun. Because it’s just like he said in Madness Journal 2.0—there’s another hiding place.
zh: 這都是因為他在「狂人日記2」中寫到的那樣——他還有另外一個密室。

en: “Maybe—”
“Stop talking,” Jerry says, and he puts his hand out.
zh: 「不要說話。」傑瑞沖他揮了揮手。

en: He’s thinking about what he wrote in the journal. He’s thinking about those bottles of gin.
zh: 他在想他到底在日記中還寫了什麼，那些杜松子酒到底在哪裡。

en: “Jerry? Are you okay?”
zh: 「傑瑞，你還好嗎？」

en: The writing backups weren’t under the floor, but he kept them somewhere safe and secure. Somewhere close.
zh: 書稿的備份不在地板下面，但他肯定把它們放在了一個他可以高枕無憂的地方。

en: They wouldn’t be in the garage, or the kitchen, or a bedroom. Wouldn’t be somewhere he’d have to go looking for.
zh: 肯定就在附近某個地方，不會在車庫裡，也不會在廚房裡或卧室里，不會在他找過的某個地方。

en: You used to hide them.
zh: 「你把它們藏了起來。

en: You were paranoid somebody would come into your house one day and steal your computer, steal everything you worked with, steal your next big idea. “Were my writing backups found?”
zh: 你固執地以為有一天有人摸進你的屋子，偷走你的電腦，偷走你的工具，偷走你的手稿，竊取你的靈感。」

en: “Backups?
zh: 「備份？

en: I have no idea.”
zh: 我不知道。」

en: He thinks about his office.
zh: 他想起他的寫作房。

en: Remembers the layout. His mind is becoming warm, the vodka and juice flowing through all the neural pathways in his brain, quickly fogging his thoughts the way it will to somebody who hasn’t touched a drop of alcohol in nearly a year, but it’s clearing things in other areas as those thoughts link across time, the way alcohol can do that, linking images, dragging out the random, and he’s back in his study where he’s pouring himself a drink, and those bottles of gin . . .
zh: 他記得它的構造與布局，他感到一股股暖流湧上大腦，伏特加和果汁湧進大腦的所有神經通路，迅速模糊了他的思維，對於一個近一年沒有碰過一滴酒精的人來說，這種作用尤為明顯。

en: “The backups were hidden. I always hid that stuff,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我把書稿的備份都藏起來了，以前我總是把這些東西藏起來。」

en: “Under the floor maybe?”
zh: 「在地板下面？」

en: “There was nothing under the floor.”
zh: 「地板下沒有。」

en: “Then where?
zh: 「那麼藏在哪裡了？

en: Think, Jerry, come on, you’re almost there, you’re—”
zh: 你好好想想，傑瑞，加把勁，你就快想起來了，你——」

en: “Shut up,” Jerry says.
zh: 「閉嘴。」傑瑞說。

en: It has to be somewhere else big enough to fit a few bottles of gin. Where?
zh: 那個地方一定足夠大，所以能夠容納幾瓶杜松子酒。

en: Not the bookcase. Not the desk. Nothing hidden in the wall. Nothing in the roof.
zh: 在哪裡？不是書櫃，不是桌子，牆上是不可能的，屋頂更塞不下東西，沙發下面或裏面也藏不了東西。

en: Wait . . .
zh: 等等

en: nothing hidden in the wall?
zh: ……牆上藏不了東西？

en: Are you sure about that?
zh: 你確定嗎？

en: “I almost have it,” he says.
zh: 「我快想起來了。」他說。

en: Hans says nothing.
zh: 漢斯什麼也沒說。

en: “Just let me think,” he says, closing his eyes, and there he is, it’s a workday and every day was a workday back when he used to write, weekends and weekdays were all the same.
zh: 「讓我想想。」他說著，閉上眼睛。他想象著自己坐在寫作房裡，這天是工作日，他寫作的時候就是工作日，周末和平日都一樣，連他生日那天也不休息。

en: He’d work on his birthday. He’d even let Henry Cutter out of the bottle for an hour or two on Christmas Day to get those thoughts down.
zh: 聖誕節那天，他也會和亨利·卡特討論個把小時，把一些想法記錄下來。

en: That was the life of a writer— keep writing, keep moving forward, stay ahead of the crowd because if you don’t get that story written down then somebody else would.
zh: 這就是一個作家的生活——不斷寫作，不斷前進，把他人甩在身後。如果你止步不前，寫不出精彩的故事，那麼別人就會超越你。

en: He’s in his office, he’s building the word count, and he’s wrapping up for the day and he needs to make a backup, needs to get those words secure, because to lose a few thousand of them, let alone an entire manuscript . . .
zh: 他坐在寫作房裡填滿格子。這天，他結束了一天的寫作，需要做個備份，他要保證這些詞語的安全，不會丟失它們，更不用說整個手稿……作為一個作家，這種事情是斷斷不能發生的。

en: His office, his desk, he’s putting a flash drive into his computer, copy, paste, then he’s taking the flash drive back out.
zh: 他把一個快閃記憶體盤接入電腦，複製，粘貼，然後把快閃記憶體盤拔|出|來。然後呢？

en: Then what? What does he do next?
zh: 他下一步該做什麼？

en: Getting out of his chair.
zh: 離開他的椅子。

en: Past the couch and to the wardrobe.
zh: 走過沙發，走向衣櫃。

en: He opens the wardrobe door and— “Jerry—”
zh: 他打開衣櫃門——「傑瑞——」

en: Crouches down. There’s a box that holds half a dozen reams of paper there. He pushes it aside then— “You have to focus, Jerry.”
zh: 他蹲下來，裏面有一個盒子，盒子裏面有六張紙，他把它推到一邊——「你要集中精力，傑瑞。」

en: Presses the bottom corner of the wall. An opposite corner juts out.
zh: 按動牆的底角，這時對面的牆角會推出來。

en: It’s a false wall, no taller than his forearm but the width of the wardrobe.
zh: 這是面假牆，比他的前臂略低，和衣櫃同寬。

en: He pulls it away, and there’s the gin, there are the flash drives, one for each novel, there’s the gun and there’s— “I know where the journal is,” he says, and he stands up so quickly he bangs against the table.
zh: 他把它拉開，裏面有杜松子酒，有快閃記憶體盤，有每部小說的手稿，有槍，還有——「我知道日記在哪裡了。」他說，他起身太快，撞在桌子上。

en: The glass slides towards Hans, who catches it before it can fall.
zh: 酒杯滑向漢斯，他在酒杯落地之前接住了它。

en: “At the house?”
zh: 「在屋子裡？」

en: “In my office,” Jerry says.
zh: 「在我的寫作房裡。」傑瑞說。

en: “Then let’s go.”
zh: 「那我們走吧。」

en: “Let me grab my second journal,” Jerry says, and he’s already moving back towards the study.
zh: 「讓我拿上我的第二本日記。」傑瑞說，他已經回到書房，「我想在路上讀讀。」
